text:
This is West Run—a slow-moving creek lined
with honeysuckle and wild rose that meanders
through the mountains of West Virginia.

The tranquil scene near Morgantown is almost
picture perfect.

But look carefully at the color of the sediment
that lies beneath the water.
Fire orange on one side, milky white on the other.
This is not a healthy creek.

In fact, water quality experts say this creek
is “dead.”

What killed West Run is acid mine drainage
from coal mines.

Acidic mine water is tainting many streams
in the heart of West Virginia’s coal country.

But this isn’t just a story about drainage
and pollution—it’s also about recovery.
In more ways than one.

Paul Ziemkiewicz: Acid mine drainage is something
we have been trying to make go away for a
very long time here.

The Monongahela River that you crossed on
the way into town here used to be orange in
the early 1970s.
It’s now a fishery.

The streams that feed into it, which were
also orange to a large extent.

We are moving the clean waters in all these
streams way up to the headwaters where the
mines actually are.

Britt: That was Paul Ziemkiewicz, director
of the Water Research Institute at West Virginia

University, who tells us improved oversight
and treatment technology are helping restore
water quality.

Over the past several decades, the state of
West Virginia has started treating the discharge

from many shuttered coal mines, such as the
Omega mine shown here.

And active mines are required to treat acid
mine drainage with lime or some other neutralizing

agent to prevent streams and rivers from ending
up like West Run.

If left untreated, acid mine drainage contaminates
water, giving it a rust taste, harming aquatic

life, and corroding infrastructure such as
bridges.

It’s also responsible for the stream discoloration
you saw earlier.

Acid mine drainage occurs from mines when
coal contains a lot of pyrite, or iron sulfide.

The pyrite reacts with oxygen and water to
form sulfuric acid and iron 2+, or ferrous
iron.

Between pH 3 and 3.5, Fe2+ reacts with oxygen
and hydroxides to form Fe3+ ferric hydroxides,
which precipitate as orange solids.

Acid mine drainage also typically contains
high levels of aluminum and manganese, which
precipitate as hydroxides.

Aluminum hydroxide is responsible for the
milky-white sediment in West Run.

Regulations require active coal mines to treat
acid mine drainage at its source.

Paul Ziemkiewicz: So in order to take that
water, treat it, and then make that water

fit for discharge to the waters of the U.S.
under the Clean Water Act, those metals need

to be removed and the pH has to be brought
up in the range between 6 and 9.

Britt: Treating acid mine drainage leaves
behind tons of sludge that contains mostly
iron, aluminum, and manganese hydroxides.

The sludge is typically sun dried in large
ponds or in dewatering containers such as
TenCate Geotubes shown here.

Once dried, the sludge is often disposed of
underground.

Disposing of this sludge contributes to about
half of the costs associated with treating
acid mine drainage.
And that is a lot of money.

West Virginia spends millions of dollars each
year combating acid mine drainage.

Researchers like Ziemkiewicz are pioneering
another recovery effort to help bring those
costs down.

At WVU, he’s leading a project to recover
valuable rare-earth elements from the sludge,

which could help lower treatment costs for
both the coal industry and the state of West
Virginia.

Rare-earth elements are used in many products,
including cell phones, TV screens, wind turbines,

defense aircraft, and satellites used for
national security.

Although it’s too early to tell whether
WVU’s extraction process will be economical,
the technical performance looks promising.

Ziemkiewicz knew from data collected in the
1990s by the U.S. Geological Survey that acid

mine drainage entering treatment plants contains
rare-earth elements, but the water leaving
the plants does not.

He suspected that the rare-earth elements
precipitate into the sludge during treatment,
and he was right.

Paul Ziemkiewicz: So we took some samples,
analyzed them, and sure enough, the elemental

rare-earth concentration in these sludges
was much higher than you would get in the

raw acid mine drainage, the untreated acid
mine drainage.

One of the things we found out was the concentration
factor is overall about 2,600.

Britt: The question then became how to recover
the valuable rare earths from the sludge material.

The WVU team is still optimizing that process,
but here is the gist of it.

The first step is to digest the sludge in
a tank of acid such as sulfuric acid.

Paul Ziemkiewicz: Based on what we’ve seen
in the lab, we can get 90–95% of all of

the rare earths out of sludge by adjusting
the pH down to about 1.

Britt: Next, the acid solution, called the
pregnant leach solution, enters an array of
100 columns called mixer-settlers.

The first set of vessels contain an organic
phase such as kerosene and an extractant,
which binds to rare-earth elements.

This forms an emulsion containing rare earths
in the organic phase.

After removing unwanted metals from the aqueous
phase, the researchers use a strong acid to

get the rare earths back into the aqueous
phase at a higher concentration than they
started with.

The team then raises the pH, allowing the
rare earths to precipitate as a purified sludge.

Paul Ziemkiewicz: Not all rare-earth elements
are created equal.

Some of them are valuable and some of them
are not.

So one of the things we are doing is optimizing
recovery of valuable rare-earth elements and

not waste time and money extracting things
that aren’t very useful.

Rare earths are needed for many modern day
commodities, and the U.S. is keen to have

a ready source of them at hand for national
security reasons.

Paul Ziemkiewicz: As high-tech industries
have grown, the rare-earth elements demand
has grown with it.

Unfortunately, we don’t have a domestic
supply of rare-earth elements, so we import

virtually all of our rare-earth elements from
People's Republic of China.

That is where it becomes a matter of domestic
importance.

Britt: The U.S. Department of Energy agrees
that it is critically important for national

security to have a domestic source of rare-earth
elements, especially in light of the current
trade war between the U.S. and China.

Britt: You can read more about this work and
other rare-earth recovery efforts from coal-related
products in my July 9 cover story for C&EN.
